selected_quotes: Cool: Arabidopsis cooperates with neighbours and grows its leaves away from them but only if neighbours are relatives
Plants move their leaves to avoid shading other plants - but only do so for closely-related plants #kinRecognition
Do #Arabidopsis leaves detect neighbors, relatives… and friends? YES, by Casal lab
Plants detecting related neighbours through photoreceptors
Argentinos descubrieron que las plantas reconocen a sus vecinas Paper: cc @fabibiotec

citation.abstract: Although cooperative interactions among kin have been established in a variety of biological systems, their occurrence in plants remains controversial. Plants of Arabidopsis thaliana were grown in rows of either a single or multiple accessions. Plants recognized kin neighbours and horizontally reoriented leaf growth, a response not observed when plants were grown with nonkin. Plant kin recognition involved the perception of the vertical red/far-red light and blue light profiles. Disruption of the light profiles, mutations at the PHYTOCHROME B, CRYPTOCHROME 1 or 2, or PHOTOTROPIN 1 or 2 photoreceptor genes or mutations at the TRYPTOPHAN AMINOTRANSFERASE OF ARABIDOPSIS1 gene required for auxin (growth hormone) synthesis impaired the response. The leaf-position response increases plant self-shading, decreases mutual shading between neighbours and increases fitness. Light signals from neighbours are known to shape a more competitive plant body. Here we show that photosensory receptors mediate cooperative rather than competitive interactions among kin neighbours by reducing the competition for local pools of resources.
citation.title: Photoreceptor-mediated kin recognition in plants.

wikipedia.title: Kin recognition
wikipedia.summary: Kin recognition (kin detection) refers to an organism's potential ability to distinguish between close genetic kin and non-kin.

wikipedia.title: Crown shyness
wikipedia.summary: Crown shyness is a phenomenon observed in some tree species, in which the crowns of fully stocked trees do not touch each other, forming a canopy with channel-like gaps.
